{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3572712,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:24:46.348Z","cooked":"

Our team is using two Raspberry PI 5 coprocessors on our robot running a custom apriltag detection software. The PIs have an arducam OV9782 plugged into the usb port. The PIs stay nice and cool when running our detection pipeline with our cpu usage hovering around 70%. Each pi is being powered with a Pollolu 5v 3.4a buck converter, a converter which I have seen being praised across this forum for its robustness to voltage drops. The converter is plugged directly into the PDH. And the voltage from the converter is injected into the PI through a cut up USB-C cord.

The issue we are facing is seemingly randomly the raspberry PIs will enter a shutdown state. We need to manually hit the PI’s power button to bring the Raspberry PIs back to life. The weird part is the randomness at which it happens. It might be while driving or it might be while the robot is sitting still with low current draw. I think we have even hit the brownout limit for the RIO and the PIs have stayed on.

Is it caused by the regulators overheating (we wrapped them in electric tape to protect against shavings and they don’t feel super hot)? Is the regulator underpowered (we haven’t measured current draw or voltage reaching the PI but 3.4 should be enough)? Or are the PIs shutting off from shock loads on the robot (they are mounted on a lexan bellypan and it doesn’t always shutoff while driving)?

If anyone can help by thinking of reasons this is being caused or ways to address it we would be grateful as we are going to DCMP this week with a auto that leverages apriltag feedback heavily.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:24:46.348Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":81,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":430.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":497373,"topic_slug":"raspberry-pi-5-shutting-down-on-robot","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pololu.com/product/4892","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pololu - 5V, 3.4A Step-Down Voltage Regulator D30V30F5","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53544,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming, CAD"},"post_url":"/t/raspberry-pi-5-shutting-down-on-robot/497373/1","custom_user_title":"Programming, CAD","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3572727,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:34:26.384Z","cooked":"

Possibilities:

  1. Bad USB-C cable or soldered connection.
  2. Overheating, although the Pis should reduce throughput before shutting down. Check your FPS.
  3. Insufficient or bad breaker. 10A should be fine.
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:34:26.384Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497373,"topic_slug":"raspberry-pi-5-shutting-down-on-robot","display_username":"Doug Kavner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/raspberry-pi-5-shutting-down-on-robot/497373/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572751,"name":"","username":"TyJac42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyjac42/{size}/230279_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:45:18.837Z","cooked":"

1: The USB-C cable having a poor solder joint or too much resistance might have some merit. I have considered that and it may be something to test. The gauge of wire on that cable was not inspiring confidence. Soldering over the robot doesn’t lead to the best quality, but I do know what I am doing when making splices. Do you think it would be better if I injected power through the GPIO 5v header?

2: The PIs haven’t been at risk of overheating, the FPS has been fine and when I remote into them they are running at like 65 degrees C.

3: Maybe. I have tried moving them from the automotive ports to the full sized ports to no avail.

TyJac42:

Do you think it would be better if I injected power through the GPIO 5v header?

That’s how we do it.

That is good to know. I think we will try that and see how it goes. Otherwise we might throw some portable power banks on the robot and just power it that way.

Thanks for your response.

Do any of the symptoms described in this thread I started sound familiar to you?

Trouble connecting with Orange Pi when cameras connected Programming
Our programmers are having trouble with using an Orange Pi to compress the video stream to be sent to the driver station. The following is a summary from our lead programmer. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance. Two Arducam OV9782s run through PhotonVision on an OPI 5 Two cameras connected through the two USB-A ports After installing high current 12V to 5V converter (9A), Dashboard would connect to the Orange Pi After replacing two Arducams, cameras could connect to dash…
